G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28 and 31.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 and 31, and venue is proper because this matter involves the custody and parenting schedule for a minor child who resides primarily in Barnstable County.

Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 208,.proposition: Under Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 208, § 28, the Court may modify a custody or parenting order upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and a determination that modification is in the best interest of the child.

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: In Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006), the Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court reaffirmed that the overriding concern in custody matters is the best interests of the child, which includes examining the practicality and feasibility of parenting schedules.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The SJC repeatedly states that the removal decision turns on the children’s best interests and explicitly frames that standard as requiring consideration of all circumstances, including how relocation affects the feasibility of the existing shared physical custody arrangement. The opinion discusses at length the impact of distance, travel time, and the practical ability of each parent to exercise parenting time, which directly involves examining the practicality and feasibility of the parenting schedule. Thus, it reaffirms the best-interests standard in a way that encompasses practical scheduling considerations.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “We conclude that in such a situation ‘cause shown’ pursuant to G. L. c. 208, § 30, means a showing that removal is in the ‘best interests’ of the children taking into account all the circumstances and weighing the factors as described below. … It is a question for a judge, taking into account all of the facts, whether an increase in travel time between households and schools brought about by removal, and other burdens of distance, will significantly impair either parent’s ability to exercise existing responsibilities, and ultimately whether removal is in a child’s best interests.”

Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: In Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012), the Court stated that a parenting arrangement adversely affecting a child’s education and well-being constitutes sufficient grounds for modification.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: The opinion applies the best-interests standard for an initial custody determination, not a petition to modify an existing custody or parenting order. While it recognizes that instability, wrongful removal, and alienating behavior that harm a child’s well-being justify awarding primary physical custody to the other parent, it does not discuss or set the standard for modification of an existing parenting arrangement. Thus, it does not stand for the specific proposition that an arrangement adversely affecting a child’s education and well-being constitutes sufficient grounds for modification.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “However, the judge must weigh ‘all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child.’ … The judge shall consider ‘whether or not the child’s present or past living conditions adversely affect his physical, mental, moral or emotional health.’ G. L. c. 208, § 31. Factors a judge may weigh are whether one parent’s home is more stable in terms of a parent’s work schedule, whether siblings are being raised together, and whether one parent seeks to undermine the relationship a child has with the other parent.”

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: The exhaustion and educational impact faced by the child herein falls squarely within the type of circumstances the Court reviewed in cases such as Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985), and Murphy v. Murphy, 82 Mass. App. Ct. 186 (2012), which emphasize the Court's broad discretion in modifying custody orders to protect the physical and emotional welfare of children.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: Yannas addresses the standard for removal of children from the Commonwealth by a custodial parent (“real advantage” test) and the trial judge’s discretion in determining best interests in that removal context. It does affirm broad discretion in custody-related decisions, but it does not involve modification of existing custody orders in response to a child’s exhaustion or educational impact, nor does it focus on protecting children from such specific harms. Using Yannas as authority for modifying custody orders due to a child’s exhaustion and educational difficulties overstates and mischaracterizes its holding.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “Cases involving removal of a child from the jurisdiction present difficult choices. Unless one is to apply a fixed but arbitrary rule, the issue can be resolved only on a case by case basis. The effect on the child of any removal is most important. An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change … and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.”

Murphy v. Murphy, 82 Mass. App. Ct. 186.raw_text: Murphy v. Murphy, 82 Mass. App. Ct. 186 (2012)
Murphy v. Murphy, 82 Mass. App. Ct. 186.proposition: The exhaustion and educational impact faced by the child herein falls squarely within the type of circumstances the Court reviewed in cases such as Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985), and Murphy v. Murphy, 82 Mass. App. Ct. 186 (2012), which emphasize the Court's broad discretion in modifying custody orders to protect the physical and emotional welfare of children.
Murphy v. Murphy, 82 Mass. App. Ct. 186.support_reasoning: Murphy is a removal/custody case emphasizing the judge’s broad discretion to determine the child’s best interests, but it does not involve or discuss a child’s “exhaustion and educational impact” from a parenting plan or similar circumstances. The opinion focuses on relocation standards (Yannas vs. Mason), primary caretaker status, and general best-interests analysis, not on modifying custody orders due to a child’s physical or educational strain. Thus, citing Murphy specifically for the proposition that it covers exhaustion and educational impact similar to the present child’s circumstances overstates its holding and context.
Murphy v. Murphy, 82 Mass. App. Ct. 186.relevant_excerpt: “‘The best interests of a child is the overarching principle that governs custody disputes in the Commonwealth.’… ‘The judge is afforded considerable freedom to identify pertinent factors in assessing the welfare of the child and weigh them as [he] sees fit.’… A custody determination requires a ‘realistic, commonsense judgment’… and evaluates them in light of the ‘well-being of the child and [her] future development.’… In view of the trial judge’s superior position to observe witnesses and weigh evidence, we review only for abuse of discretion.”
